original_case: A 12-year-old Syrian boy was transferred to our hospital with complaints of recurrent bilious vomiting, constipation, and crampy abdominal pain for 6 days. His physical examination showed abdominal distention and tenderness. The vital signs were stable, and there was mild dehydration. All laboratory results were normal. Plain X-rays revealed a dilated bowel with air–fluid levels. An upper gastrointestinal contrast study showed dilated bowels in the upper part of the abdomen, including the stomach, duodenum, and jejunum . Intravenous fluids were administered, and nasogastric tubes were placed. On laparotomy, a band was found connecting the mesentery of the descending colon to the mesentery of the jejunum, with an entrapped loop of jejunum between the band and the mesentery . The appearance of the intestines was normal with normal blood supply. This band was ligated and excised without bowel resection . Histological examination revealed fibrotic tissue with blood vessels and no malignant changes.
rewritten_case:
A young boy from Syria, approximately 12 years old, was brought to our hospital presenting with intermittent bouts of bilious vomiting, sporadic constipation, and varying episodes of crampy abdominal pain. The exact duration of these symptoms could not be precisely determined. Upon physical examination, the boy displayed signs of abdominal tenderness and distention. His vital signs remained stable, though there was evidence of slight dehydration. Laboratory results returned no abnormalities. A plain X-ray unveiled a dilated bowel with air-fluid levels. A subsequent upper gastrointestinal contrast study showed dilatation of the upper abdominal bowels, inclusive of the stomach, duodenum, and jejunum. Intravenous fluids were given, and nasogastric tubes were implemented.

A laparotomy procedure revealed a band connecting the mesentery of the descending colon and the mesentery of the jejunum, with a loop of jejunum entrapped between the band and the mesentery. The intestines appeared normal, with a healthy blood supply. The band was ligated and excised without necessitating bowel resection. A histological examination of the band showed fibrotic tissue with blood vessels and no signs of malignancy. The observations and surgical findings were consistent with a diagnosis of Congenital intestinal obstruction due to a mesenteric band.
model_response: DX: Congenital intestinal obstruction due to a mesenteric band.
correct_diagnosis: Congenital intestinal obstruction due to a mesenteric band.
predicted_dx_raw: Congenital intestinal obstruction due to a mesenteric band.
predicted_dx_normalized: congenital intestinal obstruction due to a mesenteric band
adjudication_notes: Exact/normalized match to true dx alias.

original_case: Here we present a case of a middle-eastern female patient who developed onychotillomania at the age of 17 years. The patient was a healthy Middle Eastern teenage female who developed symptoms around the age of 16 years, precipitated by a stressful event. The patient experienced recurrent, intrusive, distressing, and time-consuming obsessional thoughts of being surveilled through her phone. These obsessions also made her functionally impaired. Consequently, the patient started to avoid using the phone and eventually damaged it. Nevertheless, her symptoms persisted even with a new phone. Furthermore, the patient was worried about harm to her family, although this symptom did not qualify as an anxiety disorder. The patient had no other symptoms, nor did her symptoms meet the criteria for psychotic disorders. She was under the care of another physician at the time of onset of the condition, and was treated with fluoxetine, which was changed to paroxetine with clear justification. The patient commenced paroxetine 20 mg titrated to 30 mg daily and started showing improvements. However, 5 months later, her symptoms relapsed with depressive features and floating passive suicide ideation. Additionally, she demonstrated nail picking that was mainly directed towards the big toes and the skin around the nails using only her fingers. On examination, the lateral nail fold was erythematous and swollen with bleeding in both big toes, which may indicate a distolateral ingrowth and the nails showed scales and signs of distal nail tearing by the patient. Sometimes the patient’s injuries required bandaging (Figs. 1 and 2). These symptoms were distressing, occurred daily, and were preceded by an urge and followed by a relief. However, they were not difficult to resist, which could be due to the paroxetine intake at the time. This complaint was not related to anxiety or depressive symptoms, and the patient had no other body-focused repetitive behaviors. Subsequently, the dose of paroxetine was increased to 40 mg. Two months later, the patient started to experience side effects that included weight gain and difficulty in urination. Medication was switched to fluoxetine at a dose of 20 mg titrated, which was later increased to 40 mg daily. After the resolution of symptoms, upon the patient’s request, 6–7 months later, the medication was reduced. The fluoxetine dose was tapered and discontinued over 3 months without any relapse in symptoms. However, 2–3 months later, the symptoms relapsed and treatment with fluoxetine 20 mg was recommenced. At the time of writing this report, approximately 2 months after restarting fluoxetine, the patient’s condition had partially improved and the nail-picking behavior remained remitted.
rewritten_case:
In this narrative, we discuss the case of a female patient of Middle Eastern descent who, at some point during her late teenage years, began to exhibit signs of onychotillomania. Initially, the patient was a healthy individual who reported the onset of symptoms following a significant stressful event. The patient started experiencing persistent, intrusive, disturbing, and time-consuming obsessional thoughts that she was being watched through her phone, leading to a notable impairment in her daily functioning. As a result, she developed an aversion to using her phone and went to the extent of destroying it. However, acquiring a new phone did not alleviate her symptoms. 

Moreover, the patient expressed concerns about the safety of her family, a symptom that did not align with the criteria for an anxiety disorder. She showed no other symptoms, and her condition did not meet the diagnostic criteria for psychotic disorders. During the onset of her symptoms, she was under the care of a physician who prescribed fluoxetine, which was later switched to paroxetine for reasons that were well justified. The patient began with a 20 mg dose of paroxetine, which was gradually increased to 30 mg daily, and she started showing signs of improvement.

However, after an unspecified duration, her symptoms returned, but this time they were accompanied by depressive features and passive suicidal thoughts. Furthermore, she began to engage in nail-picking behavior, focusing primarily on her big toes and the surrounding skin using only her fingers. Upon examination, her lateral nail fold was found to be red and swollen, with signs of bleeding in both big toes. This could potentially indicate a distolateral ingrowth, and the nails showed scales and signs of distal nail tearing by the patient. Occasionally, the patient’s self-inflicted injuries required bandaging. These symptoms were distressing, occurred daily, and were usually preceded by an urge and followed by a sense of relief. However, the patient did not find them excessively difficult to resist, which could be attributed to her paroxetine intake at the time. 

Despite the severity of the symptoms, they were not associated with her anxiety or depressive symptoms, and the patient did not display any other body-focused repetitive behaviors. Thereafter, her paroxetine dosage was increased to 40 mg, and after a period, she began to experience side effects such as weight gain and difficulty urinating. As a result, her medication was switched back to fluoxetine, starting with a 20 mg dose that was later increased to 40 mg daily. 

Eventually, the patient's symptoms resolved, and at her request, her medication was gradually reduced over a period. After some time off medication without any relapse of symptoms, the patient experienced a return of her previous symptoms, leading to the reintroduction of fluoxetine at a 20 mg dose. At the time of documenting this case, the patient’s condition had shown some improvement after an unspecified duration on fluoxetine, and her nail-picking behavior was in remission.

original_case: A 39-year-old Middle Eastern/Persian male with a known case of left lower extremity varicose vein was referred to our vascular surgery service with a chief complaint of left inguinal bulging since 15 years ago. He was asymptomatic and reported no pain or restrictions in movement or other clinical findings aside from the bulging, which resolved under local pressure. The patient had been misdiagnosed and operated on 10 years ago with the impression of a left inguinal hernia; however, no hernia sac was detected at that time. Five years later, the patient developed left lower extremity varicose veins. On physical examination, severe varicose veins of the left lower extremity with a soft, nonpulsatile, reducible inguinal bulging were detected that became more prominent by performing the Valsalva maneuver . Fig. 1 A Soft, nonpulsatile, reducible inguinal bulging in the left inguinal area; B color Doppler sonography of the left lower extremity venous system revealed incompetency of the left-sided saphenofemoral junction; C histopathology section of the aneurysmal lesion demonstrating dilated uniloculated mass with endothelial lining, indicative of tunica intima (arrowhead) (×100 hematoxylin and eosin stain); D the lesion’s wall cut section demonstrating thickening of the three layers of the venous histology with destruction of tunica media and its replacement by loose connective tissue with mild myxoid degeneration (×400, hematoxylin and eosin stain) Full size image On the basis of the patient features, color Doppler sonography of left lower extremity venous system was performed, which revealed left-sided saphenofemoral junction incompetence with severe flow reversal during the Valsalva maneuver . The patient was scheduled for surgery in which ligation of the left saphenofemoral junction and stripping of the saphenous vein, and stab avulsion phlebotomy of the left lower extremity varicose veins, were done. In the course of surgery, a 5 × 2 cm venous lesion with about 2 cm distance from the saphenofemoral junction was detected. . Subsequently, the lesion was resected and sent for pathological evaluation. . No complications occurred during the operation. The patient was discharged from the hospital on the next day after operation. After 1 month, the patient visited the clinic with an uneventful postoperative course and without any complaint. Fig. 2 Venous lesion with 2 cm distance from the left saphenofemoral junction Full size image
rewritten_case:
A Middle Eastern/Persian male in his late thirties, previously diagnosed with varicose veins in his left lower extremity, presented himself to our vascular surgery service. His main concern was a persistent bulge in his left inguinal area. Interestingly, the patient did not experience any pain or restriction of movement, and no other significant clinical findings were reported, apart from the bulge that became less prominent when pressure was applied. 

In the past, the patient was incorrectly diagnosed with a left inguinal hernia and underwent surgery. However, no hernia sac was found during the operation. It was sometime later when the patient began to develop varicose veins in his left lower extremity. 

On physical examination, severe varicose veins were observed along with a soft, nonpulsatile, and reducible inguinal bulge that became more prominent when the Valsalva maneuver was performed. A color Doppler sonography of the left lower extremity venous system revealed incompetence at the left-sided saphenofemoral junction. 

In light of these findings, the patient was prepared for another surgery. The procedure involved the ligation of the left saphenofemoral junction, stripping of the saphenous vein, and a stab avulsion phlebotomy of the varicose veins in the left lower extremity. During the operation, a 5 × 2 cm venous lesion was found, located a short distance from the saphenofemoral junction. The lesion was subsequently resected and sent for pathological evaluation. The operation proceeded without any complications. 

The patient was discharged from the hospital the day after the operation. Upon his return to the clinic after a period of recovery, the patient's postoperative course was uneventful and he reported no further complaints.

correct_diagnosis: Venous aneurysm of the great saphenous vein.

original_case: A 45-year-old white slavic male presented with a 4-year history of “clicking” of the right wrist. For the last 2 years, pain at the right wrist joint level and fourth finger flexion failure had also occurred. All the symptoms were induced by wrist and fourth finger flexion and extension. Recently, the patient had noted weakening of the right wrist. Examination did not reveal any visible or palpable pathology at the wrist level. Weakening of the right wrist was noted while the patient was grabbing the examiners’ hand. Neurological examination revealed reduced sensitivity (pain) via the median nerve area at the right wrist. Triggering at the right wrist was noted during flexion and extension of the radiocarpal joint. Despite the obvious presence of carpal tunnel syndrome, Tinel’s sign was not present. MRI of the right wrist was performed: no pathological masses were seen inside the carpal tunnel. The compression of the right median nerve was confirmed by electroneuromyography. Carpal tunnel release was performed. The tumor was attached to the flexor superficialis tendon sheath and was moving through the carpal tunnel via fourth finger and wrist flexion and extension. The tumor was excised, and the wound was closed . A morphological study was performed . Immunohistochemical analysis was performed for differential diagnosis with peripheral nerve tumors . The tumor was composed of cells with a myoid phenotype . The postoperative protocol included positioning the hand in a resting splint, regular wound dressings, and antibiotics for 3 days. All fingers were left free for regular active finger exercises. The patient was discharged after 3 days of the postoperative period. Sutures were removed after 2 weeks after surgery. The patient was followed up at 2, 4, and 6 weeks after the operation. During the last follow-up visit, there were no signs of trigger wrist or carpal tunnel syndrome.
rewritten_case:
A white slavic male in his mid-forties presented with a history of a clicking sound in his right wrist, the duration of which was not definitively known. Alongside this, he experienced pain at the joint level of the same wrist and a failure in the flexion of his fourth finger. These symptoms were often triggered by flexion and extension of the wrist and fourth finger. The patient also reported a general weakening of the right wrist, the timeline of which was uncertain.

Upon examination, there were no visible or palpable abnormalities at the wrist level. However, notable weakening was observed when the patient attempted to grip the examiners' hand. A neurological examination found reduced sensitivity to pain in the area of the right wrist served by the median nerve. During the movements of the radiocarpal joint, triggering was observed at the right wrist. Despite these signs pointing towards carpal tunnel syndrome, Tinel's sign was absent.

An MRI of the right wrist did not reveal any pathological masses within the carpal tunnel. Electroneuromyography confirmed the compression of the right median nerve. Following these findings, a carpal tunnel release was conducted. It was found that a tumor was moving through the carpal tunnel via fourth finger and wrist flexion and extension, attached to the flexor superficialis tendon sheath. The tumor was successfully excised and the wound was subsequently closed.

A series of tests, including a morphological study and immunohistochemical analysis, were performed for differential diagnosis with peripheral nerve tumors. The tumor was comprised of cells exhibiting a myoid phenotype.

Postoperative care involved the positioning of the hand in a resting splint, regular wound dressings, and a course of antibiotics. The patient's fingers were left free for regular active exercises. He was discharged after a period of observation and recovery. The sutures were removed at a subsequent appointment. Follow-up visits were scheduled for the patient, but the exact timeline was not specified. During the final follow-up, no signs of trigger wrist or carpal tunnel syndrome were observed.

correct_diagnosis: Oval-shaped fibroma in the carpal tunnel.

original_case: An 81-year-old Japanese woman was referred to our hospital for endoscopic treatment under the diagnosis of early stage gastric cancer (biopsy tub1–2) based on esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) screening. She had no history of illness, and biochemical parameters and tumor markers were within normal limits. Helicobacter pylori antibodies were negative, and EGD showed atrophic changes associated with previous H. pylori infection. An irregular depressed lesion measuring 25 mm in diameter was found on the posterior wall of the lower body (Fig. 1 a, b). Narrow-band imaging (NBI) revealed a demarcation line consistent with the surface of the depression . The surface structure within the depression was obscured, and the vessels were of variable caliber, with a network or collapsed network structure . Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with a well-differentiated intramucosal adenocarcinoma [tubular adenocarcinoma (tub1–2)], and endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) was performed . The resected specimen had the following histological parameters: 28 × 28 mm, type 0–IIc, pT1b(submucosa (SM) 900 μm), pUL(−), Ly(+), v(−), pHM0, pVM0 . Histologically, the tumor was composed of two components [tub2 adenocarcinoma and neuroendocrine cell carcinoma (NEC)], and it showed submucosal and lymphatic invasion. As shown in Fig. 2 c, histopathological examination revealed tub2 adenocarcinoma in the anal-side depression. In the oral-side depression, tumor cells lacked glandular structures and had nested trabecular or acinar-like structures. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and CD56, and chromogranin partially, confirming the diagnosis of NEC. We determined that additional surgical resection was necessary due to submucosal and lymphatic invasion and laparoscopic pyloric gastrectomy was performed. The resected specimen showed no histological remnant of cancer and no metastasis in all the dissected lymph nodes.
rewritten_case: An elderly Japanese woman was presented to our hospital for endoscopic treatment after being diagnosed with early stage gastric cancer (biopsy tub1–2) following an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) screening. She had no previous illnesses, with her biochemical parameters and tumor markers within the normal range. Antibodies for Helicobacter pylori were not detected, however, EGD indicated atrophic changes resulting from a past H. pylori infection. An irregular depression measuring 25 mm in diameter was identified on the posterior wall of the lower body. Narrow-band imaging (NBI) showed a demarcation line in line with the surface depression. The surface structure within the depression was not clear, and the vessels varied in size with a network or collapsed network structure. These findings led to a diagnosis of a well-differentiated intramucosal adenocarcinoma [tubular adenocarcinoma (tub1–2)], and an endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) was carried out. The resected specimen had the following histological attributes: 28 × 28 mm, type 0–IIc, pT1b(submucosa (SM) 900 μm), pUL(−), Ly(+), v(−), pHM0, pVM0. The tumor was histologically composed of two components [tub2 adenocarcinoma and neuroendocrine cell carcinoma (NEC)], with signs of submucosal and lymphatic invasion. As per the histopathological examination, tub2 adenocarcinoma was found in the anal-side depression. In contrast, the oral-side depression lacked glandular structures, with tumor cells showing nested trabecular or acinar-like structures. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and CD56, and partially for chromogranin, leading to the confirmation of NEC diagnosis. With the presence of submucosal and lymphatic invasion, it was determined that further surgical resection was required, and a laparoscopic pyloric gastrectomy was performed. The resected specimen showed no remaining cancerous tissue, and there were no signs of metastasis in any of the dissected lymph nodes.

original_case: A 77-year-old Asian man with diabetes mellitus, arteriosclerosis obliterans, and hypertension developed persistent plantar ulcers after percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) of the right lower extremity, which was performed by his previous physician. He was referred to our hospital after the enlargement of the plantar ulcer with an increase in pus discharge, which made it difficult to walk. Radiography revealed that the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe was destroyed and showed osteolytic changes . A biochemical analysis revealed the following: white blood cell (WBC), 9.710^9/L; red blood cell (RBC), 4.210^12/L; c-reactive protein (CRP), 13.8 mg/L; and hemoglobin (Hb)A1c, 6.8% (National Glycohemoglobin Standardization Program; NGSP). The PTA findings included complete occlusion of the middle portion of the anterior tibial artery, 75% occlusion of the proximal portion of the posterior tibial artery, and 95% occlusion of the peroneal artery. Fig. 1 Pus discharge of the right plantar ulcer increased and the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe was destroyed and showed osteolytic changes. Yellow circle indicates osteolytic areas Full size image Because no fever was observed and an immediate incision could be performed, systemic antibiotics were not administered. An extended plantar incision was performed at the pus drainage hole between the first and second metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint to a depth just above the periosteum under local anesthesia. No sequestrectomy or removal of flexor tendons was performed, as is commonly done. After making an extended incision, the patient was instructed to take a daily foot bath in carbonated water (AS care; Asahi Kasei Medical Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) at 37 °C with a carbon dioxide concentration of 1000–1300 ppm for 15 minutes at home. We also advised him to continue applying povidone–iodine sugar ointment (U-PASTA; Kowa Company, Ltd., Nagoya, Japan) to the wound after the foot bath. After 6 months of biweekly wound examinations, wound closure and bone and joint remodeling were observed, and the therapy was concluded. At 1 year 5 months later, the lesion had not recurred, and radiography demonstrated the regeneration of a joint-like structure in the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe, allowing the patient to walk normally : an unexpected event in the course of treating this patient. Since this method uses carbonic acid and sugar, we tentatively called it soda pop therapy. Fig. 2 One year and five months later, the wound was healing and radiographs showed the regeneration of a joint-like structure in the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe. Yellow circle indicates the regeneration of a joint-like structure Full size image
rewritten_case: A 77-year-old Asian man, plagued with diabetes mellitus, arteriosclerosis obliterans, and hypertension, developed chronic plantar ulcers following a percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) on his right lower extremity, executed by a prior physician. The patient was referred to our hospital due to the aggravation of the plantar ulcer, which displayed an increase in pus discharge, causing walking difficulties. Radiography depicted the destruction of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe and osteolytic transformations. A biochemical analysis yielded the following results: white blood cell (WBC), 9.710^9/L; red blood cell (RBC), 4.210^12/L; c-reactive protein (CRP), 13.8 mg/L; and hemoglobin (Hb)A1c, 6.8% (National Glycohemoglobin Standardization Program; NGSP). Moreover, PTA findings noted complete occlusion of the middle portion of the anterior tibial artery, 75% occlusion of the proximal portion of the posterior tibial artery, and 95% occlusion of the peroneal artery. The image of the right plantar ulcer displayed an increased pus discharge, and the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe was destroyed and showed osteolytic changes. The yellow circle represents osteolytic areas. The absence of a fever and the possibility of immediate incision meant systemic antibiotics were not administered. An extended plantar incision was performed on the pus drainage hole between the first and second metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint to a depth just above the periosteum under local anesthesia. Standard procedures like sequestrectomy or removal of flexor tendons were not performed. Post incision, the patient was directed to take a daily foot bath at home in carbonated water (AS care; Asahi Kasei Medical Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) at 37 °C with a carbon dioxide concentration of 1000–1300 ppm for 15 minutes. He was also advised to apply povidone-iodine sugar ointment (U-PASTA; Kowa Company, Ltd., Nagoya, Japan) to the wound following the foot bath. After half a year of biweekly wound examinations, wound closure and bone and joint remodeling were observed, and the therapy was concluded. At a follow-up, 1 year and 5 months later, there was no recurrence of the lesion, and radiography revealed the regeneration of a joint-like structure in the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe, enabling the patient to walk normally. This was an unanticipated outcome in the treatment of this patient. Since this method employs carbonic acid and sugar, we tentatively named it soda pop therapy. The one year and five-month follow-up showed the wound was healing, and radiographs displayed the regeneration of a joint-like structure in the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe. The yellow circle indicates the regeneration of a joint-like structure. Given the patient's lack of response to antibiotics and his clinical and imaging findings, a diagnosis of other osteomyelitis was highly considered.
model_response: observed.
correct_diagnosis: Osteomyelitis due to methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

original_case: The patient was a 28-year-old Iranian man who presented with right shoulder pain and hoarseness 1 week prior to admission. Going through his medical records, we realized that he had undergone an open right subclavian artery bypass for acute right upper extremity ischemia caused by thrombosis in the aneurysmal right subclavian artery to the distal arterial branches around 1.5 years ago. However, follow-up imaging suggested occlusion in the bypass area. Given the history of recurrent oral aphthous lesions and extensive body folliculitis lesions, a specific condition was suspected. The diagnosis was confirmed by a positive human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-B*51 test, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 79, and a C-reactive protein (CRP) of 5.2 (normal: 0.5), as well as pathological findings from the open right subclavian artery bypass surgery. Cyclophosphamide therapy was the treatment of choice for the patient, but due to infertility concerns, he refused. Therefore, he was treated with azathioprine 100 mg daily, prednisolone 30 mg daily, colchicine 1 mg daily, and rivaroxaban 20 mg daily postoperatively. The patient’s compliance was good, and according to the latest rheumatological reports prior to his admission to our facility, his condition was under control and no hypercoagulable symptoms were observed. After admitting the patient, with all his past history in mind, we requested a contrast-enhanced chest computed tomography angiography (CTA) with suspicion of a vascular pathology causing pressure effect on the recurrent laryngeal nerves. CTA revealed a 32 × 27 mm ruptured pseudoaneurysm originating from innominate artery bifurcation with a 90 × 61 × 65 mm hematoma extending to the right shoulder and forming an extrapleural hematoma at the apex of the right thoracic cavity . The trachea was deviated to the left side due to the mass effect of the pseudoaneurysm. Despite total occlusion of the right subclavian and axillary arteries by thrombosis, the patient had no complaint regarding his right upper extremity, which shows that there was probably sufficient collateral blood perfusion. Even though we retrospectively reexamined his previous CTA from the former admission, no anomaly was found in the innominate artery. We decided to repair the ruptured pseudoaneurysm by an endovascular approach. Preoperatively, the patient received methylprednisolone to decrease postoperative complications. In a hybrid operation room, we performed a digital subtraction angiography. Unfortunately, owing to the lack of proper landing zone, we could not perform an endovascular repair by stent graft. Inevitably, we approached the pseudoaneurysm by a median sternotomy with supraclavicular extension. After excising the ruptured pseudoaneurysm and evacuating the surrounding hematoma, we performed an innominate artery to the right common carotid artery bypass with a 6 mm expandable polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) graft, which passed right behind the innominate vein . The pressure effect of the pseudoaneurysm was removed from the right recurrent laryngeal, phrenic, and vagus nerves with no neural damage. We decided not to perform a right subclavian artery bypass since it was previously thrombosed, and the patient had no complaint concerning the right upper extremity.
rewritten_case:
A 28-year-old Iranian male patient presented with complaints of right shoulder discomfort and voice hoarseness that had persisted for a week before he was admitted. The patient's medical history revealed an open right subclavian artery bypass operation approximately 1.5 years earlier due to acute ischemia in the right upper extremity, which was triggered by thrombosis in the aneurysmal right subclavian artery spreading to the distal arterial branches. Subsequent imaging showed an occlusion in the bypassed area. 

Given the patient's history of recurrent oral aphthous and extensive body folliculitis lesions, a specific condition was suspected. Diagnostic tests revealed a positive human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-B*51 test, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 79, and a C-reactive protein (CRP) level of 5.2 (normal: 0.5). Despite these findings, the patient's clinical picture alongside the presence of a severe headache and blurred vision raised the suspicion of a nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage. 

On admission, considering the patient's medical history, we ordered a contrast-enhanced chest computed tomography angiography (CTA) suspecting a vascular anomaly that could be exerting pressure on the recurrent laryngeal nerves. The CTA revealed a 32 × 27 mm ruptured pseudoaneurysm originating from the innominate artery bifurcation and a 90 × 61 × 65 mm hematoma extending to the right shoulder, forming an extrapleural hematoma at the apex of the right thoracic cavity. The trachea was deviated to the left due to the mass effect of the pseudoaneurysm. 

Despite the total occlusion of the right subclavian and axillary arteries by thrombosis, the patient did not report any discomfort in his right upper limb, suggesting sufficient collateral blood flow. Retrospective examination of his previous CTA from the earlier admission did not reveal any abnormalities in the innominate artery. 

Interestingly, the patient's neurological symptoms along with the presence of blood in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) obtained through lumbar puncture, steered the diagnosis towards a nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage. However, the presence of a pseudoaneurysm and the patient's history of Behçet's syndrome suggested a more complex clinical scenario. 

The patient was taken to a hybrid operation room for a digital subtraction angiography. Unfortunately, due to an inadequate landing zone, an endovascular repair by stent graft was not feasible. Consequently, a median sternotomy with supraclavicular extension was performed to access the pseudoaneurysm. After the ruptured pseudoaneurysm was excised and the surrounding hematoma evacuated, a bypass was performed from the innominate artery to the right common carotid artery using a 6 mm expandable polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) graft. The pseudoaneurysm's pressure was relieved from the right recurrent laryngeal, phrenic, and vagus nerves without any neural damage. The right subclavian artery bypass was not performed as it was previously thrombosed and the patient reported no discomfort in the right upper extremity. 

Despite the initial misleading findings pointing towards a subarachnoid hemorrhage, the final diagnosis was Behçet's syndrome with a ruptured pseudoaneurysm of the innominate artery.
model_response: of a pseudoaneurysm in the innominate artery, which was not detected in the previous CTA, raised the suspicion of a secondary cause for the subarachnoid hemorrhage.
correct_diagnosis: Behçet's syndrome (BS) with ruptured pseudoaneurysm of the innominate artery.
target_distractor: Nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage from unspecified carotid siphon and bifurcation

original_case:
A 74-year-old Japanese man presented to the previous hospital complaining of right hip pain. There was no history of trauma. His history included appendicitis and hypertension. X-rays showed no obvious abnormalities , so further examinations were performed. The computed tomography (CT) scan showed evidence of sclerosis with a periosteal reaction in the right supra-acetabulum . Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with T1 weighting showed a linear low signal and an equivalent signal surrounding it at the right supra-acetabulum, and the linear low signal and high signal surrounding it were seen on the T2-weighted image. The lesion was not suppressed by short TI inversion recovery. Contrast-enhanced MRI showed the lesion gradually enhanced . A malignant bone tumor at right supra-acetabulum was suspected by CT and MRI, and he was referred to our department. Blood testing was carried out for differential diagnosis considering bone metastasis from carcinoma or secondary osteoporosis. There were no inflammatory findings in the blood results, nor were there any abnormalities in his electrolytes, thyroid hormones, or tumor markers. rewritten_case:
A Japanese man in his seventies arrived at a previous hospital with complaints of pain in his right hip. There was no record of any trauma-induced event. His medical history revealed conditions such as appendicitis and hypertension. Initial X-rays did not disclose any clear abnormalities, prompting further examination. 

An advanced computed tomography (CT) scan was performed, revealing signs of sclerosis along with a periosteal reaction in the right supra-acetabulum. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with T1 weighting showed a linear low signal and an equivalent signal surrounding it at the same location. T2-weighted imaging showed the same linear low signal and high signal surrounding it. The lesion was not suppressed by short TI inversion recovery, and contrast-enhanced MRI demonstrated gradual enhancement of the lesion. 

These findings led to the suspicion of a malignant bone tumor at the right supra-acetabulum, and the patient was subsequently referred to our department. Blood testing was conducted to consider differential diagnosis, including the possibility of bone metastasis from carcinoma or secondary osteoporosis. The results showed no inflammatory markers, and the patient's electrolytes, thyroid hormones, and tumor markers were all within normal ranges. 

In addition to these tests, nuclear examinations were carried out to differentiate between benign or malignant lesions and to identify potential other bone lesions. Both bone scintigraphy and positron emission tomography (PET) revealed accumulation in the right supra-acetabulum. The PET scan showed a standardized uptake value (SUV) max of 3.5 at the site. 

Among the potential diagnoses considered were primary malignant bone tumor, like osteosarcoma, a right supra-acetabular metastasis, or a right supra-acetabular incomplete fracture (IF). In order to confirm the diagnosis, a CT-guided needle biopsy was performed. The biopsy results showed the absence of tumor cells but revealed the formation of osteoids and the infiltration of inflammatory cells, indicating a healing process likely following a fracture. 

Subsequent imaging was performed to assess the patient's bone density. The L2–L4% young adult mean (YAM) was 66% (normal value ≥ 80%), which was indicative of osteoporosis. Bloodwork showed an elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level of 558 IU/L (normal value 50–350), and the total type I procollagen N-terminal propeptide (totalP1NP) was 115 µg/L (normal value 18.1–74.1). These results are consistent with a healing fracture. 

No adverse or unanticipated events occurred during the patient's assessment and treatment.

original_case: A 15-year-old white Latin American female patient underwent contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for outpatient investigation of persistent pelvic pain. In a recent emergency department (ED) visit for the same complaint, a normal urinalysis was obtained. Her past medical history was unremarkable, and she did not take any medications and denied alcohol, tobacco, or any drug abuse. Few minutes after receiving gadolinium during MRI, she presented to the ED with shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting. Upon admission, she had a brief period of loss of consciousness and her vital signs were as follows: blood pressure (BP), 84/40 mmHg; temperature, 36.4 °C; heart rate (HR), 122 beats per minute; respiratory rate (RR), 30 breaths per minute, and peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 78%. Her pulmonary auscultation revealed bilateral rales, but she did not have rash, or tongue or lip swelling. Despite significant hypoxemia, she was able to speak in whole sentences, and inhaled oxygen was delivered through a non-rebreather mask (NRBM) at 10 L per minute. She immediately received 500 mg of hydrocortisone and a 1 L bolus of intravenous crystalloids, but epinephrine was not administered upon the patient’s presentation. Also, antimicrobial therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin was initiated. Laboratory tests demonstrated a hemoglobin level of 18.6 g/dL, a slightly elevated white blood cell count (15,360/mm3, normal 4000–11,000/mm3), an increased C-reactive protein (CRP) concentration (41.8 mg/L, normal: < 0.5 mg/L), a lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level of 176 U/L (normal 135–214 U/L), and a d-dimer concentration of 1.7 mg/mL (normal: < 0.5 mg/mL). B-type natriuretic peptide and troponin levels were low, and the echocardiogram was normal. A chest computed tomography (CT) was performed around 1 hour after GBCA administration and showed bilateral pulmonary compromise secondary to multiple confluent consolidations located mainly in the posterior aspects of the lower lobes. There were also regions of ground-glass opacities that were more evident in the upper lobes along with diffuse thickening of interalveolar septa . A CT pulmonary angiography ruled out the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. A severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) nasopharyngeal swab testing came back negative. Fig. 1 Chest computed tomography (CT) showing bilateral multiple confluent consolidations located mainly in the posterior aspects of the lower lobes associated with regions of ground-glass opacities in the upper lobes and diffuse thickening of interalveolar septa Full size image She was then transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) with improved vital signs: BP, 119/71 mmHg, HR, 122 beats per minute, and SpO2 of 93%. Due to high oxygen requirement, methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg was prescribed and she was commenced on bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) ventilation and high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC). The patient showed substantial improvement over the following 12 hours, which enabled her to be weaned off noninvasive ventilatory support. She was afebrile during the entire hospital stay. She was discharged from ICU on day 2 receiving inhaled oxygen via nasal cannula at 1 L per minute and discharged home on day 3, with SpO2 of 98% on room air. Owing to the patient’s rapid recovery after supportive treatment and the absence of clinical evidence of infection, the decision to cease antibiotic therapy was made. Corticosteroid treatment was tapered down slowly over 30 days after discharge. Six months after initial presentation, the patient remained well and the follow-up was uneventful.
rewritten_case:
A 15-year-old Latin American female patient presented for outpatient contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) due to ongoing pelvic pain. Prior to this, during a recent emergency department (ED) visit for the same complaint, a normal urinalysis was obtained. Her past medical history was unremarkable, with no medications, alcohol, tobacco, or drug abuse. Shortly after receiving gadolinium for the MRI, she was brought to the ED with symptoms of shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting. She briefly lost consciousness upon admission, and her vital signs were as follows: blood pressure (BP), 84/40 mmHg; temperature, 36.4 °C; heart rate (HR), 122 beats per minute; respiratory rate (RR), 30 breaths per minute, and peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 78%. Her lungs had bilateral rales, but no rash, or tongue or lip swelling were observed.

Despite her significantly low oxygen levels, she was able to speak in full sentences. Oxygen was delivered through a non-rebreather mask (NRBM) at 10 L per minute. She received 500 mg of hydrocortisone and a 1 L bolus of intravenous crystalloids. Epinephrine was not administered. Ceftriaxone and azithromycin were initiated as a part of antimicrobial therapy. Laboratory tests showed slightly elevated white blood cell count (15,360/mm3, normal 4000–11,000/mm3), increased C-reactive protein (CRP) concentration (41.8 mg/L, normal: < 0.5 mg/L), a lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level of 176 U/L (normal 135–214 U/L), and a d-dimer concentration of 1.7 mg/mL (normal: < 0.5 mg/mL). Her hemoglobin level was unusually high at 18.6 g/dL, suggestive of a potential hypoxic response. 

A chest CT performed around 1 hour after the contrast agent administration revealed bilateral pulmonary compromise secondary to multiple confluent consolidations primarily in the posterior aspects of the lower lobes. Ground-glass opacities were more evident in the upper lobes along with diffuse thickening of interalveolar septa, a sign often seen in drug-induced interstitial lung diseases. CT pulmonary angiography ruled out pulmonary embolism. SARS-CoV-2 nasopharyngeal swab testing was negative.

She was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) with improved vital signs: BP, 119/71 mmHg, HR, 122 beats per minute, and SpO2 of 93%. Due to the high oxygen requirement, methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg was prescribed, and she was started on BiPAP ventilation and high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC). Within the next 12 hours, the patient showed substantial improvement, allowing her to be weaned off noninvasive ventilatory support. She remained afebrile during the entire hospital stay and was discharged from ICU on day 2 on nasal cannula oxygen at 1 L per minute. She went home on day 3, with an SpO2 of 98% on room air. Given her rapid recovery and no clinical evidence of infection, antibiotic therapy was discontinued. Corticosteroid treatment was gradually tapered off over 30 days post-discharge. Six months after her initial presentation, the patient remained well, with an uneventful follow-up. The clinical picture suggested an acute episode of drug-induced interstitial lung disorder, potentially triggered by gadolinium, rather than an infectious cause.

original_case: A 45-year-old Japanese woman was referred to our department due to a severe headache. Twenty-one years prior, she was diagnosed with left clavicle ES and underwent surgical tumor excision. Preoperative and postoperative chemotherapy, consisting of vincristine, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, ifosfamide and etoposide were respectively administered. The patient also had a history of left breast cancer, treated with pectoral muscle-sparing mastectomy. Preoperative and postoperative chemotherapy, consisting of docetaxel, pertuzumab, trastuzumab, fluorouracil, epirubicin, and cyclophosphamide, were respectively administered 2 years prior. On admission, the patient presented with a headache, but no neurological findings were noted. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the brain showed a tumor extending superiorly and inferiorly from the cerebellar tent, along the left occipital bone with a contrast enhancement effect (Fig. 1 a, b). Osteolytic changes were observed in the left occipital bone . Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain revealed the tumor, exhibiting an isodense signal intensity on T1-weighted  and T2-weighted imaging . No signal was noted in the left transverse sinus on magnetic resonance venography. This suggested occlusion due to tumor invasion . The tumor extended to the left mastoid air cells. On 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose-positron emission tomography (18F-FDG PET), the tumor exhibited a low uptake . No high uptake regions were observed throughout the entire body . Fig. 1 Precontrast head computed tomography (CT) shows a high-density lesion bordering the left occipital bone (a), and the contrast-enhanced head CT shows a contrast enhancement effect (b). Osteolytic changes are also observed in the left occipital bone (c). On the head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), the lesion exhibits isodense signal intensity on T1-weighted imaging (d) and T2-weighted imaging (e). Magnetic resonance venography shows no signal in the left transverse sinus (f). 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (18F-FDG) positron emission tomography-CT reveals low 18F-FDG uptake in the tumor (g) and no abnormally high uptake throughout the body (h) Full size image Following admission, a small craniotomy and biopsy were performed to confirm the pathological diagnosis. Pathological examination showed small round cells with scanty cytoplasm on hematoxylin–eosin staining . CD99 immunohistochemistry showed strong membranous staining among the tumor cells . Periodic acid-Schiff detected small positive granules in the cytoplasm . A craniotomy and subtotal tumor excision were performed the following day. After the subtotal removal of the tumor, her headache improved. Fig. 2 Hematoxylin–eosin staining shows small round cells with little cytoplasm (a ×200). Immunohistochemical staining shows a membranous expression of CD99 (b ×200). Periodic acid-Schiff staining detected small positive granules (c ×200). Ki-67 staining shows that the MIB-1 index is about 30% (d × 200) Full size image During the craniotomy, a yellowish-white neoplastic lesion was observed in the epidural space across the transverse sinus . A portion of the tumor infiltrated the dura and extended to the surface of the brain. The tumor was removed as completely as possible, and the left transverse sinus was resected. However, the tumors in the left mastoid air cells and left sigmoid sinus could not be excised. Postoperatively, intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) at 61.2 Gy was administered in 34 fractions. Head MRI after IMRT showed a small residual tumor (Fig. 3 b, c). Fig. 3 Craniotomy was performed across the transverse sinus. A yellowish-white tumor (asterisk) was observed in the epidural space (a). Head MRI after intensity-modulated radiation therapy shows the residual tumor in the left mastoid air cells and sigmoid sinus; however, it is smaller than that before radiotherapy (b, c) Full size image
rewritten_case:
A middle-aged Japanese woman came to our department with a severe headache. She had a history of left clavicle Ewing's sarcoma (ES), for which she underwent surgical tumor excision. Her treatment included preoperative and postoperative chemotherapy regimens of vincristine, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, ifosfamide, and etoposide. The patient also had a past diagnosis of left breast cancer, which was treated with pectoral muscle-sparing mastectomy. The preoperative and postoperative chemotherapy for this condition included docetaxel, pertuzumab, trastuzumab, fluorouracil, epirubicin, and cyclophosphamide. 

Upon examination, the patient reported a headache, but no neurological findings were noted. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the brain revealed a tumor originating from the cerebellar tent and extending along the left occipital bone with a contrast enhancement effect. Osteolytic changes were observed in the left occipital bone. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) displayed an isodense signal intensity on T1-weighted and T2-weighted imaging, with no signal in the left transverse sinus on magnetic resonance venography, suggesting occlusion due to tumor invasion. The tumor also extended to the left mastoid air cells. 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose-positron emission tomography (18F-FDG PET) showed the tumor demonstrating a low uptake, with no high uptake regions observed throughout the body.

A small craniotomy and biopsy were performed for a pathological diagnosis, which revealed small round cells with scanty cytoplasm on hematoxylin–eosin staining. CD99 immunohistochemistry showed strong membranous staining among the tumor cells, while periodic acid-Schiff detected small positive granules in the cytoplasm. A subsequent craniotomy and subtotal tumor excision were performed, which alleviated the patient's headache.

During the craniotomy, a yellowish-white neoplastic lesion was observed in the epidural space across the transverse sinus. Some of the tumor had infiltrated the dura and extended to the surface of the brain. The tumor was removed as much as possible, and the left transverse sinus was resected. However, tumors in the left mastoid air cells and left sigmoid sinus could not be excised. Following this, the patient underwent intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) at 61.2 Gy in 34 fractions. Post-treatment, a head MRI showed a small residual tumor.

original_case: The patient was an 8-year-old, previously healthy, and fully immunized Iranian girl who was initially presented to the pediatric emergency department with 5 days of intermittent fever, followed by abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She had not attended school within the last 6 months and was cared for by her parents. She was an active child, but staying home most of the time because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Her parents had signs and symptoms compatible with mild upper respiratory tract infection since 1 week before. She had recently received oral antibiotic and intravenous serum as outpatient care. She was admitted with fever and abdominal pain in the surgery service of Akbar Hospital with suspected appendicitis. Nausea and vomiting persisted. According to normal sonography findings and persistent symptoms and emergence of rash and conjunctivitis, she was referred to the pediatric COVID-19 ward. She did not have cough, congestion, or rhinorrhea. After the third day, she received co-trimoxazole and ondansetron. Physical examination revealed bilateral nonpurulent conjunctivitis, erythematous throat, palmar erythema, strawberry tongue, and erythema multiform rash  without hypotension. There was no lymphadenopathy or retraction breathing, with normal respiratory sounds. There were no focal signs of infection. On cardiac examination, there was an II/VI murmur on the left sternal border. According to fever (38.6 °C) and pandemic state of COVID-19, she underwent lung high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT), which was not indicative for COVID-19 infection. Laboratory evaluation included urinalysis with urine culture, all with negative results. On laboratory examination, ESR was 67 mm/h, CRP 166 mg/L, platelets 192 × 10^9/L, hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL and WBC 10.3×10^9/L (PMN: 82%). Moreover, other routine biochemistry and liver function tests yielded normal findings. Fig. 1 Nonpurulent conjunctivitis, Strawberry tongue, palmar rash Full size image She received IVIG (2 g/kg; 1 g/kg on two consecutive days) and high-dose acetylsalicylic acid (20 mg/kg four times daily) according to rheumatology consultation. Echocardiography showed no pathology related to coronary arteries. Besides, respiratory tract viral infections were evaluated by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test for COVID-19 and blood culture, all with negative results. There was no history of recent travel. Nonetheless, her parents had flu-like symptoms along with hypogeusia and anosmia. She was hospitalized for 5 days. The day before discharge, serologic tests for COVID-19 infection in her parents (serum IgM more than 1.1) and the child herself became positive (serum IgM COVID-19 of 2.1). Consequently, the public health department was notified, and the family was instructed to quarantine at home for 14 days from the positive test result date.
rewritten_case:
The patient was an 8-year-old, previously healthy, and fully immunized Iranian girl who was initially brought to the pediatric emergency department after experiencing 5 days of intermittent fever, followed by abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She was a home-based child, having not attended school for the past 6 months due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and was cared for by her parents. Her parents had exhibited signs and symptoms consistent with a mild upper respiratory tract infection a week prior.

Despite being an active child, she spent most of her time at home due to the pandemic situation. Recently, she had received outpatient care in the form of oral antibiotics and intravenous serum. Upon presenting to Akbar Hospital with fever and abdominal pain, she was initially suspected to have appendicitis. However, her symptoms persisted, including nausea, vomiting, and the emergence of a rash and conjunctivitis, despite normal sonography findings.

The patient was subsequently referred to the pediatric COVID-19 ward, despite not exhibiting common symptoms such as cough, congestion, or rhinorrhea. On the third day of her stay, she was given co-trimoxazole and ondansetron. Physical examination revealed bilateral nonpurulent conjunctivitis, an erythematous throat, palmar erythema, a strawberry tongue, and an erythema multiform rash, but no hypotension. No lymphadenopathy or retraction breathing was observed, and her respiratory sounds were normal. There were no focal signs of infection.

On cardiac examination, an II/VI murmur was detected on the left sternal border. Due to her ongoing fever (38.6 °C) and the current COVID-19 pandemic, she underwent a high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scan of the lungs, which did not indicate a COVID-19 infection. Laboratory evaluation included urinalysis and urine culture, both of which were negative. However, her ESR was 67 mm/h, CRP 166 mg/L, platelets count at 192 × 10^9/L, hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL, and WBC 10.3×10^9/L (PMN: 82%). Routine biochemistry and liver function tests were within normal limits.

Interestingly, her blood culture showed the presence of Brucella organisms, a common cause of brucellosis, a disease known for its nonspecific symptoms including fever, abdominal pain, and nausea. The child received IVIG (2 g/kg; 1 g/kg on two consecutive days) and high-dose acetylsalicylic acid (20 mg/kg four times daily) as per rheumatology consultation. Echocardiography did not show any pathology related to coronary arteries.

Further evaluation for respiratory tract viral infections via reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) testing for COVID-19, along with blood culture, all yielded negative results. The patient had no recent history of travel. However, her parents had been experiencing flu-like symptoms, including hypogeusia and anosmia.

She was hospitalized for 5 days. The day before discharge, serologic tests for COVID-19 infection in her parents (serum IgM more than 1.1) and the child herself became positive (serum IgM COVID-19 of 2.1). Consequently, the public health department was notified, and the family was instructed to quarantine at home for 14 days from the positive test result date. With the presence of Brucella organisms in her blood and the nonspecific symptoms, a diagnosis of brucellosis was considered.

original_case: A 9-year-old African-American male with a history of steroid-dependent NS presented to the nephrology clinic for routine follow-up care in September 2018. He had been diagnosed with NS at 4 years of age, and had multiple relapses and hospitalizations for management of his disease. He was up-to-date with all his immunizations, including vaccination for S. pneumoniae; he had received PCV7 as the initial series and a booster of PCV13. He was receiving mycophenolate mofetil 200 mg twice a day for about 6 months and prednisone 30 mg on alternate days for about 1 month. The child’s only complaint was neck pain and stiffness that had begun 1–2 days prior to presentation. His mother attributed the neck pain to muscle tightness and stated that massages to the area provided some pain relief. There was no history of recent illness, fever, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, headache, seizures, or altered mental status. On physical examination, he was afebrile and had mild periorbital swelling and edema on lower extremities. He appeared ill, exhibited neck rigidity, and revealed reflex knee flexion on neck flexion. He was transferred to the emergency department (ED) for further evaluation and management. On admission to the ED, his temperature was 99 °F, heart rate 112 beats per minute, respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute, blood pressure 101/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. The child persisted with neck stiffness, and roughly 7 hours after presenting to the ED, he developed fever (102 °F). At this time, a lumbar puncture was performed to rule out meningitis. Laboratory evaluation showed mild anemia, leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance, hyponatremia, elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), and an elevated sedimentary rate. Cerebrospinal results demonstrated pleocytosis, with very decreased glucose level. Laboratory findings are summarized in . The patient was started on ceftriaxone 100 mg/kg/day and vancomycin 15 mg/kg/day, and was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) for close cardiopulmonary monitoring and further management. By the second day of hospitalization, both cerebrospinal and blood cultures grew S. pneumoniae, which was pansensitive, including to ceftriaxone. Vancomycin was discontinued and the child remained on ceftriaxone monotherapy at 100 mg/kg. He was restarted on daily steroid therapy to attain remission of the NS. While in the PICU, the patient developed persistent hypertension and was treated with enalapril 5 mg twice a day. Amlodipine 5 mg once a day was added later as a second antihypertensive to further optimize blood pressure (BP) control. The child was transferred to the inpatient ward where he completed a 2-week course of ceftriaxone with no complications. His overall edema improved, and his BP was controlled on two antihypertensive drugs.

original_case: A 46-year-old East Asian male with a history of Crohn’s disease (diagnosed in November 2018 with duodenitis, duodenal ulcers, ileitis, and colitis with crypt abscess) reported to have no psychosocial disorder nor significant family history. He was treated with immunomodulators including an initial treatment of azathioprine 50 mg and prednisolone 15 mg twice daily, and mesalazine. Owing to remission of the clinical symptoms of Crohn’s disease, prednisolone was gradually tapered off; prednisone use covered a total period of 3 months. Following 4 months of azathioprine and 3 months of prednisolone use, the patient complained of persistent abdominal pain and diarrhea. Endoscopy in March 2019 revealed scarring in the colon and terminal ileum. Furthermore, inflammatory polypoid lesions were noted in the terminal ileum that were not present in a previous examination . Results of a biopsy revealed that spindle cells were arranged in intersecting fascicles with intervening slit-like vascular spaces containing erythrocytes located in the submucosal layer. Immunohistochemistry revealed immunoreactivity for CD34, smooth muscle actin (SMA), and HHV-8. Stainings for CD117, DOG1, and cytomegalovirus were all negative . These findings supported a diagnosis and excluded a diagnosis of gastrointestinal stromal tumor. Fig. 1 Endoscopy showed polypoid lesion of the terminal ileum. Biopsy of the polypoid tumor and histopathology identified a condition. Full size image Fig. 2 Histopathology of the condition in the terminal ileum. Spindle cells were arranged in intersecting fascicles with intervening slit-like vascular spaces containing erythrocytes located in the submucosal layer. A Fascicles of spindle cells (short arrow) and extravasated erythrocytes (long arrow) on Hematoxylin and Eosin stain (× 400). B Spindle cells on Hematoxylin and Eosin stain (× 1000). C Immunohistochemical staining for CD 34 was positive (× 400). D Immunohistochemical staining for HHV-8 was positive (× 400) Full size image The patient was tested for HIV, hepatitis C virus, and herpes simplex virus, with negative results. Physical examination revealed no cutaneous manifestations. Small bowel series indicated multiple smooth-surface round filling defects throughout the jejunum to the ileum, compatible with intraluminal polypoid tumors . Abdominal computed tomography (CT) revealed diffuse edematous change of the gastrointestinal tract and multiple nodular lesions in the small bowel . Therefore, we reduced administration of azathioprine 50 mg from twice to once daily and reintroduced prednisolone to control the symptoms of Crohn’s disease. Fig. 3 Small bowel series indicated (A) Multiple smooth-surface round filling defects throughout the jejunum to the ileum (arrows) (B) Multiple smooth-surface round filling defects over the ileum, compatible with polypoid tumors (arrows) Full size image Fig. 4 Abdominal CT scan revealed diffuse edematous change of gastrointestinal tract and multiple hyperdense nodular lesions in the small bowel (arrows) Full size image The oncologist began chemotherapy with eight courses of epirubicin 100 mg. After 6 months, endoscopy and CT revealed complete remission of the condition, and the symptoms of Crohn’s disease were stable. During chemotherapy, doses of the aforementioned immunomodulators were kept constant, and doses of prednisolone were adjusted ranged from 2.5 mg twice daily to 10 mg twice daily according to variations in the clinical activity of the patient’s Crohn’s disease. Following chemotherapy, the patient was monitored with CT every 4 months in the first year and every 6 months in subsequent years. rewritten_case: A 46-year-old East Asian male with a history of Crohn’s disease (diagnosed in November 2018 with duodenitis, duodenal ulcers, ileitis, and colitis with crypt abscess) reported to have no psychosocial disorder nor significant family history. He was treated with immunomodulators including an initial treatment of azathioprine 50 mg and prednisolone 15 mg twice daily, and mesalazine. Owing to remission of the clinical symptoms of Crohn’s disease, prednisolone was gradually tapered off; prednisone use covered a total period of 3 months. Following 4 months of azathioprine and 3 months of prednisolone use, the patient complained of persistent abdominal pain and diarrhea. Endoscopy in March 2019 revealed scarring in the colon and terminal ileum. Furthermore, inflammatory polypoid lesions were noted in the terminal ileum that were not present in a previous examination . Results of a biopsy revealed that spindle cells were arranged in intersecting fascicles with intervening slit-like vascular spaces containing erythrocytes located in the submucosal layer. Immunohistochemistry revealed immunoreactivity for CD34, smooth muscle actin (SMA), and HHV-8. Stainings for CD117, DOG1, and cytomegalovirus were all negative . These findings supported a diagnosis and excluded a diagnosis of gastrointestinal stromal tumor. Fig. 1 Endoscopy showed polypoid lesion of the terminal ileum. Biopsy of the polypoid tumor and histopathology identified a condition. Full size image Fig. 2 Histopathology of the condition in the terminal ileum. Spindle cells were arranged in intersecting fascicles with intervening slit-like vascular spaces containing erythrocytes located in the submucosal layer. A Fascicles of spindle cells (short arrow) and extravasated erythrocytes (long arrow) on Hematoxylin and Eosin stain (× 400). B Spindle cells on Hematoxylin and Eosin stain (× 1000). C Immunohistochemical staining for CD 34 was positive (× 400). D Immunohistochemical staining for HHV-8 was positive (× 400) Full size image The patient was tested for HIV, hepatitis C virus, and herpes simplex virus, with negative results. Physical examination revealed no cutaneous manifestations. Small bowel series indicated multiple smooth-surface round filling defects throughout the jejunum to the ileum, compatible with intraluminal polypoid tumors . Abdominal computed tomography (CT) revealed diffuse edematous change of the gastrointestinal tract and multiple nodular lesions in the small bowel . Therefore, we reduced administration of azathioprine 50 mg from twice to once daily and reintroduced prednisolone to control the symptoms of Crohn’s disease. original_case: A 35-year-old Brazilian man with HIV for 10 years who was non-adherent to ART (lamivudine + abacavir + dolutegravir) was admitted with a history of successfully treated histoplasmosis. He had been hospitalized for 1 month at a public hospital in Natal, Brazil, with initial symptoms of intense diarrhea, daily fevers, sweating, and chills for 3 weeks. He was diagnosed with disseminated TB, and tuberculostatic treatment (isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, streptomycin, and pyrazinamide) was given for 10 days. However, due to increased transaminase levels, his regimen was changed to levofloxacin, capreomycin, and ethambutol. He was observed for 10 days and discharged. Thirteen days after discharge, he was admitted to the referral health service in Recife, Brazil, with a worsening of his clinical condition characterized by fever, dyspnea, pain in the upper and lower limbs and spine, and cough. Prophylactic treatment with sulfamethoxazole + trimethoprim + piperacillin/tazobactam was initiated. Lymphocyte counts showed that patient was severely immunocompromised, with a CD4 count of 8 cells/mL, CD8 count of 347 cells/mL, and CD4/CD8 ratio of 0.02. A high viral load was detected (174,034 copies). Several laboratory tests were requested, including fungal investigations because of his history of histoplasmosis 2 years prior and the finding of several whitish plaques in his oral cavity . Blood culture, bronchoalveolar lavage, and oral secretions were obtained. The samples were sent to the Laboratory of Diagnostic in Tropical Diseases at the Federal University of Pernambuco, and slides were made for direct examination (Fig. 1b, c) to visualize fungal structures. Spherical yeast cells were observed in large numbers. Fig. 1a White-yellowish plaques on the tongue. b, c Direct mycological examination of the oral secretion showing hyaline yeast cells without dye (b) stained with methylene blue (c) (magnification: ×400). d–f Thickened pericardium with areas of hyperechogenicity in the left ventricular wall and absence of pericardial effusion Full size image Each biological sample was cultured on Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (Difco, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) + chloramphenicol in duplicate, and the plates were maintained at 28 °C and 37 °C. There was rapid growth with sporulation after 3 days of culture. Yeasts were identified using the VITEK® 2 automated microbial identification system (bioMérieux SA, Marcy-l'Étoile, France) and matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight–mass spectrometry according to Lima-Neto et al. [11]. Both methods identified Candida tropicalis. In vitro antifungal susceptibility tests were performed according to the protocol described in the 2008 Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) document M27-A3 [12] and using the VITEK® 2 system with the AST YS01 card; both tests confirmed the identification. Candida tropicalis isolates showed resistance to fluconazole and voriconazole, for which the minimal inhibitory concentrations (MIC) were 64 and 16 µg/mL, respectively; the MICs for anidulafungin, caspofungin, micafungin, and amphotericin B were 0.125, 0.03, 0.125, and 0.25 µg/mL, respectively. The patient was diagnosed with esophagitis. Treatment with amphotericin B deoxycholate and itraconazole with a maintenance dose was instituted. After 12 days of hospitalization, the patient developed sepsis from a pulmonary focus and his respiratory status worsened, leading to nasal intermittent mandatory ventilation. Meropenem and vancomycin were started, and itraconazole (400 mg/day) was maintained. Laboratory tests showed significant pancytopenia. Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed pericardial thickening, a sequelae of tuberculous pericarditis (Fig. 1d–f). Two days after the end of antibiotic therapy, the patient developed new fever peaks, and the medical staff chose to prolong the medication for another 10 days. Simultaneously, herpetic lesions in the genital region appeared, and acyclovir (750 mg/d) was initiated. A modified ART regimen (tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir) and tuberculostatic (COXCIP-4) therapy was given. The patient improved clinically and was stable for discharge after 30 days of hospitalization with appropriate clinical follow-up.

original_case: A 67-year-old Asian woman, who was a nonsmoker, presented to our hospital with a complaint of prolonged dry cough for 2 months. The patient also had dyspnea in the supine position, night sweats, and mild appetite loss for 1 month, but no complaints of any gastrointestinal symptoms. She was diagnosed with UC at the age of 29 years with bloody diarrhea, had been in long-term remission for over 35 years, and was taking salazosulfapyridine (1000–1500 mg/day) orally. She had no history of occupational dust exposure, but had a family history of pulmonary tuberculosis. On physical examination, her vital signs were as follows: temperature, 36.4 °C; heart rate, 99 beats per minute; blood pressure, 136/74 mmHg; respiratory rate, 16 breaths per minute; and oxygen saturation on room air, 98%. Auscultation of the neck and chest revealed normal breath sounds, without adventitious sounds. The rest of the physical examination, including the outer ear, nose, and joints, was normal. Blood analysis revealed elevated C-reactive protein (CRP; 10.71 mg/dL) and increased levels of leucine-rich α-2-glycoprotein (LRG; 44.2 μg/mL, normal < 16.0 μg/mL), a new biomarker for evaluating disease activity in patients with UC. Tumor markers, proteinase-3 anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, soluble interleukin (IL)-2 receptor, and angiotensin-converting enzyme were within normal limits, and T-SPOT.TB (an interferon-γ release assay) was negative. Chest radiography revealed narrowing of the trachea  compared with the previous year . Chest computed tomography (CT) demonstrated circumferential thickening of the tracheal wall, ranging from the trachea to the bilateral main bronchi , without lung parenchymal abnormalities. Pulmonary function tests showed a forced vital capacity of 2.81 L [114.5% of the predicted volume (pred)], forced expiratory volume in 1 second of 2.06 L (101.5% pred), and decreased peak expiratory flow of 3.11 L per second (53.3% pred). A flow–volume loop graph at the first visit revealed fixed upper airway obstruction . Fig. 1 Chest X-rays obtained at the first visit (A) and 1 year before the first visit (B), respectively. Chest X-ray at the first visit (A) showing narrowing of the trachea compared with that from a year earlier (B). C Chest computed tomography image showing circumferential thickening of the tracheal wall. D Flow–volume loop graph demonstrating fixed upper airway obstruction Full size image Her symptoms were unresponsive to treatment with oral levofloxacin (500 mg/day) or inhaled fluticasone furoate (100 μg/day)/vilanterol trifenatate (25 μg/day) administered for 1 week. Bronchoscopy performed to investigate extensive large airway disease revealed widespread edema with erythema and diffuse concentric narrowing of the bronchial lumen from the trachea to the bilateral segmental bronchi ; however, neither swelling nor paralysis of the vocal cord could be confirmed. Dynamic collapse of the central airway was not observed during respiration. Mucosal biopsy specimens revealed marked submucosal lymphocytic infiltration . No evidence of infection, malignancy, vasculitis, or amyloidosis was found. Fig. 2 A Bronchoscopic examination showing diffuse narrowing of the trachea with inflamed erythematous mucosa. B Photomicrograph of endotracheal mucosal biopsy specimen showing intense submucosal infiltration. The inset within B is a magnified view of lymphocytic infiltration. Scale bar, 20 μm Full size image Fig. 3 Clinical course from initiation of corticosteroid therapy. Chest computed tomography images obtained at the first visit, 1.5-month follow-up, and 5-month follow-up show amelioration of bronchial wall thickening. CRP C-reactive protein, ESR erythrocyte sedimentation rate, PSL prednisolone Full size image
